body: That's extremely weird. Can you post the code that caused the issue?  The specific task that failed and the one that preceded it, if possible.

It looks like the most recent failure occurred while pushing data to the engines prior to processing.  In this case, I had used the cluster previously to complete a job(successfully) and then started another job without restarting ipcluster3.

The code that led up to the failure is basically this.  A,B,C,D are numpy arrays and relatively small

```
rc = Client()
dview = rc[:]
lview = rc.load_balanced_view()

logging.info("Found {} engines".format(len(rc)))  #Found 11

start = datetime.now()
logging.info("Pushing initial arrays to Engines")

ar = dview.push(dict(A=A, B=B, C=C, D=D))  #Looks like failure happened here
ar.wait()
```

In general, the work that we're doing involves pushing numpy arrays to engines, performing crunching, and then collecting processed data from the engines.  I can't include the code that runs on the engines, but the main controller code is essentially:

```
#Push additional arrays that are specific to the current phase of processing
ar = dview.push(dict(E=E, F=F, G=G))  #These arrays are large
ar.wait()

results = []
for chunk in chunks:
    result = lview.apply_async(worker_method, (chunk,))
    results.append(result)

dview.wait(results)
for proc_result in results:
    result_chunk = proc_result.get()
    # do stuff with result_chunk            
```

Some of the arrays that we're pushing can be tens of thousands of rows by tens of columns, so maybe we're running into some sort of memory issues on our engines?  I've tried looking at the engine log files, but I haven't seen anything memory-related there.

Can you provide the full traceback?

This is extremely weird because it means that a message is arriving on a socket that should never have received it.  I have never seen that before, and I don't understand how it could happen.
You might also set client.debug = True, but that produces a huge amount of output, so if it takes a long time to reproduce, that may not be helpful.

I'll see if I can get a traceback when the error occurs again.

I do have a log file from running with client.debug = True.  Since this is from today's failure, where the failure happened relatively early in processing, the file is smaller(only 52M!).  I've filtered out the sensitive parts and am happy to post the file somewhere, or just include whatever pieces are important.  The log files quickly become unwieldy with client.debug = True(8+ gigs for a run lasting 11 hours).

If I skip over the large blocks of encoded data, I see this towards the end of the file:

``` python
{'content': {},                                                                 
 'header': {'date': datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 19, 17, 26, 4, 332720),          
            'msg_id': '02c97ad9-265f-4ab1-b597-362ff6db600c',                   
            'msg_type': 'apply_request',                                        
            'session': '57346a48-b6ca-44c7-8d1f-103767d48423',                  
            'username': 'my_user'},                                             
 'msg_id': '02c97ad9-265f-4ab1-b597-362ff6db600c',                              
 'msg_type': 'apply_request',                                                   
 'parent_header': {}}  
[b'a3623a1f-b938-41df-bd6c-c5f890030584',                                       
 b'<IDS|MSG>',                                                                  
 b'f509aa40141c9f56250b89ffe0e7e16d',                                           
 b'{"date":"2013-01-19T17:26:04.332720","username":"my_user","session":"57346a48-b6ca-44c7-8d1f-103767d48423","msg_id":"02c97ad9-265f-4ab1-b597-362ff6db600c","msg_type":"apply_request"}',
 b'{}',                                                                         
 b'{}']    
[lots of data]
Unhandled message type: apply_request
[more data]
 'content': {},                                                                 
 'header': {'date': datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 19, 17, 26, 2, 766023),          
            'msg_id': 'd3b3fa87-12ac-4fea-8465-0a825ce5cf71',                   
            'msg_type': 'apply_request',                                        
            'session': '57346a48-b6ca-44c7-8d1f-103767d48423',                  
            'username': 'my_user'},                                             
 'msg_id': 'd3b3fa87-12ac-4fea-8465-0a825ce5cf71',                              
 'msg_type': 'apply_request',                                                   
 'parent_header': {}}
# [End of file]
```

I managed to get a traceback for the most recent failure(see below).  Based on the traceback/logged statements, the exception occurred here:

```
#Push additional arrays that are specific to the current phase of processing
ar = dview.push(dict(E=E, F=F, G=G))  #These arrays are large
ar.wait()
```

```
Exception occurred during run:                                                                        
 Unhandled message type: apply_request                                                    
Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                    
  File "../../ifoo_driver.py", line 74, in <module>                                             
    main.run(opts)                                                                                                 
  File "/usr/foo/ifoo/ifoo/main.py", line 75, in run                                            
    (Final1, Final2) = foo1(…)              
  File "/usr/foo/ifoo/ifoo/main.py", line 94, in foo1                    
    CIF=CIF)                                                                                                           
  File "/usr/foo/ifoo/ifoo/parallel_foo.py", line 159, in foorize
    residual = iterate(…)
  File "/usr/foo/ifoo/ifoo/parallel_foo.py", line 190, in iterate 
    update_Foo1(...)                                                       
  File "/usr/foo/ifoo/ifoo/parallel_foo.py", line 461, in update_Foo1
    ar.wait()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.2/dist-packages/IPython/parallel/client/asyncresult.py", line 142, in wait
    self._ready = self._client.wait(self.msg_ids, timeout)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.2/dist-packages/IPython/parallel/client/client.py", line 1059, in wait
    self.spin()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.2/dist-packages/IPython/parallel/client/client.py", line 1014, in spin
    self._flush_results(self._mux_socket)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.2/dist-packages/IPython/parallel/client/client.py", line 822, in _flush_results
    raise Exception("Unhandled message type: %s"%msg_type)
Exception: Unhandled message type: apply_request                                         
```
I am also getting this error on a 6-core machine, using 6 IPython clients. My job also involves CPU-intensive operations on very large matrices.
If someone can post code to reproduce this (ideally), or `ipcontroller --debug` output of an instance, that would be much appreciated.

Nothing shows up with ipcontroller --debug, will try to create a small piece of code to reproduce it...
Now, by ipcontroller --debug, do you mean starting ipcontrollers and ipengines separately, but passing the debug flag to the ipcontroller?

I did notice that of 64GB of RAM total on mg system, 60GB was being used. This error only happens with this one particularly high-memory algorithm, so I'll investigate along those lines. 

> On Dec 19, 2013, at 7:03 PM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @alexbw yes, that's what I mean.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
It's been a very long time since this one has come up. I'm going to hope that refactoring in 3.0 has fixed it. If anyone sees this again, we can reopen.

Saw this today just trying to run the ipython starcluster example (http://star.mit.edu/cluster/docs/0.93.3/plugins/ipython.html) 

results.get() gives me the error 

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ipyparallel/client/client.pyc in _flush_results(self, sock)
    809             handler = self._queue_handlers.get(msg_type, None)
    810             if handler is None:
--> 811                 raise Exception("Unhandled message type: %s" % msg_type)
    812             else:
    813                 handler(msg)

Exception: Unhandled message type: apply_request
